Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Penn State Research Experience for Undergraduates and Teachers Program in Condensed Matter Physics and Interdisciplinary Materials Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
Penn State University continues operation of a Research Experiences for Undergraduates/Teachers Site hosted by the Penn State Department of Physics and the Penn State Materials Research Science and Engineering Center. Nineteen undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds are recruited every year for a ten-week summer research experience. Five teachers are supported every year for a six-week summer research experience.

Science teachers and students majoring in science and engineering disciplines participate in a variety of research projects in condensed matter and materials research within laboratories located in science and engineering departments at Penn State. Working with top researchers and their groups on individual research projects, students receive training and information, which prepares them for the excitement and challenges of graduate school. Teachers transfer material science knowledge to classroom activities by developing appropriate resources with their peers and Penn State faculty. Participants attend weekly professional development seminars, weekly research seminars, ethic training, machine shop courses, facility tours, a trip to the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia, and present the results of their research at a symposium.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided funding for 37 students to participate in a ten-week research experience during the summers of 2011 to 2014.  All but one of these students were from outside Penn State; she being an exceptional physics major. More than half (30) were from schools with limited research opportunities. Two were partially supported by other NSF grants. Because of our strong collaborations with other funding sources, we brought in 21 more students from outside Penn State to participate in the program activities, 17 supported by the Penn State MRSEC (Center for Nanoscale Science) and 4 supported by Penn State diversity program funds, for a total of 58 students in 4 years.

To further increase the impact of REU program, the Physics department, through departmental funds and contributions from individual faculty grants, has sponsored 46 summer research scholarships for Penn State undergraduates and 9 students from the Universidad Iberoamericana in Mexico from 2011-2014; these students participate in all REU activities and in fact act as hosts for the non-local students, often working in the same research labs, when possible. In 2014, MRSEC supported 5 more Penn State Millennium Scholars to join the REU program. This broadly defined REU program hosted an average of 30 students every summer. This grant also provided funding for 12 K-12 teachers to participate in a six week RET program within the REU site. Six of them were female and 2 were from an underrepresented minority group. Six teachers supported by RET supplements of other NSF grants also participated in our RET program. In 2014 we operated on a no-cost extension and did not run the RET program, but still ran the REU program with 2 students sponsored by DMR-1062691, 13 sponsored by the MRSEC and 13 sponsored by Penn State.

25 publications and 27 conference presentations which were produced with undergraduate and teacher researchers who participated in this program, including NSF and Penn State funded students. Of the NSF funded students participating from 2011-2013, 9 refereed publications have been produced, and 9 undergraduate students presented their research at national or regional meetings.  72% of graduated NSF funded REU students from 2011-2014 began graduate or professional school in science and engineering.
